{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3641886,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-31T22:11:26.083Z","cooked":"

Our team wants to get into robot simulation and advantagescope.
We really have not used those with the actual simulated devices, meaning - the most we have done is fed odometry to Glass, but that was coming from the robot.
We would like to do coding with the actual simulated devices, such as motor controllers, IMU etc.

Is there a tutorial on how to do so, or any kind of step-by-step guides for the simulation beginners? We prefer to start without having a robot or device model in CAD, hopefully just define a device and see how it behaves when simulated inputs are applied to it (e.g. getting encoder values etc)

The next step would be visualization - do we have to have a model defined in CAD in order to visualize anything, or there are ways to define simple mechanisms for visualization directly in code?

Any guidance on this would be appreciated.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Introduction to Robot Simulation

Often a team may want to test their code without having an actual robot available. WPILib provides teams with the ability to simulate various robot features using simple gradle commands. Java/C++ U...

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Physics Simulation with WPILib

Because state-space notation allows us to compactly represent the dynamics of systems, we can leverage it to provide a backend for simulating physical systems on robots. The goal of these simulator...

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Device Simulation

WPILib provides a way to manage simulation device data in the form of the SimDevice API. Simulating Core WPILib Device Classes: Core WPILib device classes (i.e Encoder, Ultrasonic, etc.) have simul...

atsekhan:

The next step would be visualization - do we have to have a model defined in CAD in order to visualize anything, or there are ways to define simple mechanisms for visualization directly in code?

I would recommend starting with Mechanism2d, which you can visualize both in two dimensions and in 3D on a drivebase in AdvantageScope:
